title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [27 january 1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [27 January 1867]
text: 20 Jan. 1867sundaySunday afternoonmy dear Walti must write you a few lines and only a few to let you know how we are i can hardly write on account of lameness in my right arm down toward my wrist it has been over a week at first i thought it was going to gather but it has not yet but is swolenswollen and at times pains me quite bad but i make out to doodo around but i cantcan't lift much with it i have rubbed it with one a but it dontdon't seem to doodo much good george says i must put slippery elm poultice but perhaps it will get better in time but it is so bad when i make bread and crullers george wants them to take down he was up yesterday and the day before he wasentwasn't up from last saturdaySaturday night till wensdayWednesday not last night but saturdaySaturday week it was so bad and such snow banks last week one day a waggonwagon and six horses got stuck on the avenuavenue the cars didentdidn't run those was pasengerspassengers from flatbush i suppose but they had to walk down Jeffy said they were two hours getting out O walt it is terrible here in the winter matt is getting as tired of it as i am it will not look like any thing again even in the summer its all dug and redug between this and the avenuavenue great trenches it looks like destruction ) we are all pretty well except my arm and sis she aintain't very well she is by my side asleep in the rocking chair its very rare for me to be without them i get very tired of them i often feel as if i wished to be quiet if only for one hour matty has no help so the young ones live up here perbascoProbasco has put up here since yesterday so they have it) georges horse ran away the other day from the lumber yard run till she got fast in a snow drift he thinks it wontwon't hurt her that she wontwon't run again she is a nice horse only 5 years old well walt Jeff talks of coming to washingtonWashington he is going somewhere else and talks of coming there to stay one night talks of coming next tuesday matt says he has talked of coming so many times and not come) for me to not say any thing about it but i think he will come this time maybeemaybe not tuesday but some times during the week) i receive your letter and money and envelopes as usual walt last wensdayWednesday davis sDavis's man always brings them to me i feel so glad walt you can go to see the poor fellows in the hospital and carry them a cake i suppose its quite a treat to them good bie walt write mrs mix sMix's address if i ever get out of the snow maybeemaybe i can call and see her good bie again Walter with many thanks for your remembrance ofyour mother Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [27 January 1867]
